content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

This whole slide image thumbnail displays four separate pieces of tissue. The piece in the bottom-left quadrant is a well-circumscribed, ovoid structure with dense basophilic (dark purple) staining, which is highly characteristic of a lymph node. The other tissue fragments are more irregular and could represent additional lymph nodes, adipose tissue, or sections of the primary tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist evaluating a colorectal cancer case, a key part of the staging process is to identify and examine all lymph nodes for evidence of metastasis. The area in the green box, located in the bottom-left tissue section, is clearly a lymph node. It is imperative to examine every identified lymph node at high magnification to determine if it is benign (reactive) or malignant (containing metastatic tumor cells). Therefore, I am zooming into this specific lymph node to assess its architecture and cellular components for signs of cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is almost completely replaced by a malignant infiltrate. There are dense sheets of small, dark lymphocytes mixed with larger, atypical cells that have irregular nuclei and more eosinophilic cytoplasm, consistent with metastatic carcinoma. Additionally, there are prominent features of tumor-related changes, including areas of necrosis (amorphous pink material), hemorrhage (collections of red blood cells), and numerous hemosiderin-laden macrophages (cells containing coarse brown pigment). My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, extensively involved by metastatic carcinoma with associated necrosis and hemorrhage.
